title: Deadly floods displace thousands in Thailand, Malaysia and Vietnam | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Thirteen people have been killed in southern Thailand in what's been called the area's worst flooding in 25 years. Monsoon weather is also wreaking havoc in Malaysia where at least eight people are reported to have died. Meanwhile, central Vietnam is still counting the cost of a week of torrential rainfall, which killed dozens and damaged hundreds of thousands of homes. Amanda Robson reports. title: Trump administration orders collection of migrant crime data | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The United States has ordered its embassy to begin collecting data on migrant crime from several countries, including Australia. The Trump administration continues to expand its own anti-immigration policies, with critics warning of the rise of similar divisive political movements around the world. Jared Mondschein from the United States Studies Centre tells The World the Trump administration is "completely changing how the US looks at human rights". title: Crypto crash: How Bitcoin, other digital assets lost $1 trillion in value | The World | ABC News
description: Investors in Bitcoin are reeling as the cryptocurrency's value dropped by hundreds of billions of dollars in recent weeks. The sell-off is part of a broader wipe out of more than a trillion US dollars across major digital assets. Some reports are saying Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies have hit bear market territory. The recent slump has also dealt a significant blow to US President Donald Trump and his family wealth. Eleanor Terrett, host of the 'Crypto in America' podcast, spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about what's behind the price fall and what lies ahead for investors. title: Australia's east braces for severe thunderstorms, heat and fire danger | ABC NEWS
description: Fire danger warnings have been issued for many parts of eastern Australia, with New South Wales bracing for catastrophic and extreme fire danger.  The Bureau of Meteorology is also forecasting more severe thunderstorms for south-eastern Queensland and north-eastern NSW.  Senior meteorologist Miriam Bradbury says heat, dry air and strong winds are elevating fire danger levels in areas such as Greater Sydney, the Lower and Central West plains, the Greater Hunter and the Illawarra Shoalhaven regions. title: Ukraine accepts modified US proposal for peace with Russia | ABC NEWS
description: Ukraine has reportedly accepted a modified version of a US-backed plan to end the war with Russia, saving several sensitive terms for personal discussions between Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and US counterpart Donald Trump.  Meanwhile. Washington and Moscow officials are meeting in the UAE’s Abu Dhabi to negotiate a peace deal.  Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov says the Kremlin is unlikely to agree to a deal if it deviates significantly from what Russian leader Vladimir Putin and the US president discussed in Alaska.  Meanwhile, US Secretary of State Marco Rubio joined the Coalition of the Willing’s video conference hosted by UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer and French President Emmanuel Macron in a promising sign of US cooperation.  The UK, France and Turkiye have all expressed willingness to deploy peacekeeping troops to Ukraine if a peace deal is reached. title: Is the $96m BOM website really that bad? | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Australians are all pretty invested in the weather and the Bureau of Meteorology is our go-to source of forecasts and information.    So, people noticed when the BOM changed its website and many, including farmers, complained that data sources they relied on were either missing or hard to find.    A change in the rain radar has already been rolled back and now the bureau has revealed it cost close to a hundred million dollars to build the website and all the infrastructure behind it.    Today, the ABC’s lead rural reporter in Victoria, Justine Longmore, on the BOM website debacle.   Featured:    Justine Longmore, ABC lead rural reporter, Victoria

title: Optus outage affecting Triple-Zero calls in Frankston, Mornington Peninsula | ABC NEWS
description: More than 14,000 Optus customers south-east of Melbourne have lost service, with the telco warning calls to emergency services have been impacted. Approximately 14,096 services have been impacted in the Frankston and Mornington Peninsula areas.  According to the Optus website, the issue has been caused by an "aerial fibre break" and is currently under investigation. "Optus customers will only be able to call Emergency Services if they are within coverage of another mobile network or are able to call via WiFi," the Optus website said. title: NSW warned of catastrophic fire danger amid high temperatures and strong winds | ABC NEWS
description: The NSW Rural Fire Service is warning of catastrophic fire danger – the highest warning level – with high temperatures and strong winds across the state. Total fire bans are in place in multiple regions, with RFS Deputy Commissioner Ben Millington says people need to monitor conditions and remain vigilant. title: Bird flu confirmed in elephant seal population on Australia's Heard Island | ABC NEWS
description: Samples from dead elephant seals were collected in October after scientists visiting Heard Island aboard the icebreaker RSV Nuyina observed unusual levels of mortality in the population.  The samples were tested at the CSIRO's Australian Centre for Disease Preparedness in Geelong, which has confirmed the presence of the H5 bird flu virus. title: Russia overtakes Australia in Asia Power Index | ABC NEWS
description: Russia has overtaken Australia as one of the top five most powerful countries in Asia, according to the Lowy Institute's Asia Power Index. The index assesses factors like defence networks and economic relationships. While the US remains in first place, China and Russia are gaining influence. Analyst Susannah Patton says Australia is making security commitments, but our ability to fund and follow through remains in question. title: Vitamin B6 toxicity cases prompt supplements to be restricted | ABC NEWS
description: Many vitamin B6 supplements will be removed from shelves by June 2027 due to increasing cases of B6 toxicity. Customers will need pharmacist supervision to buy products with more than 50 mg of B6, and anything over 200 mg will require a prescription. Drug safety researcher Geraldine Moses advises consumers to check their vitamins for hidden B6. title: Key figures quit Tas Shooters, Fishers, Farmers party over disagreements with only MP | ABC NEWS
description: Key figures in Tasmania's Shooters, Fishers and Farmers Party have quit their roles, following Lyons MP Carlo Di Falco's backflip on the Macquarie Point Stadium.  The first term MP backed the project when it faced the lower house, despite having stood for election opposing it — triggering accusations he had let down voters. title: Headline annual inflation rises to 3.8% | ABC NEWS
description: Annual inflation rose to 3.8 per cent in October, up from 3.6 per cent in September, despite no overall price increase that month. The trimmed mean inflation, monitored by the Reserve Bank, increased slightly to 3.3 per cent, exceeding the RBA's target range of 2-3 per cent. The report is the first complete set of monthly inflation figures from the ABS, including all goods and services in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) basket. title: Indonesian workers lose thousands of dollars in Australian visa scam | ABC NEWS
description: An ABC investigation has exposed a criminal network which has allegedly defrauded many young Indonesian workers eager to migrate to Australia.  The scammers, who claim to have connections to Indonesian immigration authorities, charge their victims more than $5,000 for a letter required for Australia’s work and holiday visa.
